sectionHeaders.researchSubtitle: Astrometric observations with Very Long Baseline Interferometery (VLBI)

researchQuestions.title: Improving Ephemeris and Frame Tie
researchQuestions.description: How can astrometric measurements enhance the Solar System ephemeris and tighten the frame tie between VLBI and pulsar timing arrays for more accurate gravitational wave detection?

researchQuestions.title: MSP Velocity and Formation Channels
researchQuestions.description: What does the peculiar velocity distribution of millisecond pulsars tell us about their formation mechanisms, including possible differences between isolated and binary MSPs?

researchQuestions.title: Correcting the Shklovskii Effect
researchQuestions.description: How can precise astrometric distances help correct for the Shklovskii effect in binary systems and enable more accurate tests of General Relativity through pulsar orbital decay?

researchQuestions.title: Tracing the Galactic Potential with MSPs
researchQuestions.description: Can newly measured MSP binaries be used to trace the Galactic gravitational potential and better constrain the distribution of dark matter in the Milky Way?

keyFindings.title: Unprecedented Parallax Precision
keyFindings.description: Using VLBA, the project achieves sub-100 microarcsecond parallax precision, enabling accurate distance measurements to dozens of millisecond pulsars—critical for mapping the Galaxy and improving gravitational wave detection models.

keyFindings.title: Refinement of Galactic Electron Density Models
keyFindings.description: Our measurements provide key data to calibrate Galactic electron density models like NE2001 and YMW16, correcting systemic biases and improving distance estimates derived from dispersion measures.

keyFindings.title: Astrometric Contributions to Pulsar Timing Arrays
keyFindings.description: By delivering precise 3D positions and motions for pulsars, this project reduces errors in pulsar timing arrays, enhancing their sensitivity to gravitational waves from supermassive black hole binaries.

pulsarJourney.title: Journey of a Pulsar
pulsarJourney.subtitle: From telescope to theory, explore how pulsar astrometry unfolds through the VLBA project

steps.title: Pulsar Discovery
steps.description: Our journey begins with the detection of radio pulses from distant neutron stars.

steps.title: Timing and Analysis
steps.description: Pulsar timing models help refine celestial coordinates and enable scheduling of precise VLBI observations.

steps.title: Astrometric Observation
steps.description: Using VLBA, we track the pulsar’s position across epochs to extract parallax and proper motion.

steps.title: Distance and Impact
steps.description: With accurate distances, we advance studies in gravitational waves, pulsar velocities, and Galactic structure.

steps.title: Scientific Discovery
steps.description: Results feed into broader astrophysical insights, including dark matter constraints and gravitational wave science.

lighthouse.title: Cosmic Lighthouses
lighthouse.description: Pulsars are rapidly rotating neutron stars – the incredibly dense remnants of massive stars that have exploded as supernovae. They emit beams of radiation from their magnetic poles that sweep across space like lighthouse beams as they rotate.

millisecond.title: Millisecond Marvels
millisecond.description: Millisecond pulsars rotate incredibly fast – hundreds of times per second, with periods between 1-10 milliseconds. For comparison, that's faster than a kitchen blender! These are among the most stable rotators in the universe, making them exceptional cosmic clocks.

binary.title: Born from Binary Systems
binary.description: Unlike regular pulsars, millisecond pulsars are thought to have been "recycled" – spun up to high speeds by accreting matter from a companion star. This process transfers angular momentum to the neutron star, dramatically increasing its rotation rate.

importance.title: Why They Matter
importance.description: The MSPSRπ project measures precise distances to millisecond pulsars across our Galaxy. These measurements help us map the Galaxy's structure, test theories of gravity, improve our understanding of interstellar space, and detect gravitational waves.

lighthouse.title: Neutron Stars
lighthouse.text: Neutron stars are incredibly dense stellar remnants. A teaspoon of neutron star material would weigh about a billion tons on Earth!

lighthouse.title: Radio Emissions
lighthouse.text: The beams of radiation are primarily radio waves. When these beams sweep across Earth, our radio telescopes detect periodic pulses of radio emission.

millisecond.title: Exceptional Timekeepers
millisecond.text: Millisecond pulsars are incredibly precise cosmic clocks. Their rotation periods are predictable to within a few nanoseconds over years of observation.

millisecond.title: Speed Comparison
millisecond.text: Regular pulsars typically rotate once every 0.1-10 seconds. In contrast, millisecond pulsars complete hundreds of rotations in a single second!

binary.title: Accretion Process
binary.text: As matter falls onto the neutron star, it forms a rapidly rotating accretion disk. The infalling matter transfers its angular momentum to the neutron star, spinning it up.

binary.title: Companion Stars
binary.text: The companion stars in these binary systems are often white dwarfs or low-mass main sequence stars that have evolved to the point where their outer layers expand and can be pulled toward the neutron star.

importance.title: Pulsar Timing Arrays
importance.text: By precisely monitoring the arrival times of radio pulses from multiple millisecond pulsars, scientists can detect tiny ripples in spacetime caused by gravitational waves.

importance.title: MSPSRπ Project
importance.text: The MSPSRπ project uses Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) to measure precise parallaxes and proper motions of millisecond pulsars, determining their exact distances and velocities.
